{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3364781,"name":null,"username":"holonomic","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/c2a13f/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T02:54:03.365Z","cooked":"

After seeing some requests in the community for more splineXS compatible products + the ability to manufacture splines in house more easily, I looked into the feasibility of having a custom broach manufactured. I have a few different quotes from overseas manufacturers, mostly coming in at the $250-$350 range at a MOQ of 1. I wanted to try and gauge interest from the broader FRC community in a product like this to get a better idea of what quantities would look like. This is all still very early, but $325-350 landed+shipped to destination is my current price target. If this is something that interests you, or if you just have input or ideas, please reply below.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":98,"updated_at":"2024-04-18T02:54:03.365Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":319,"reads":1545,"readers_count":1544,"score":2234.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":463206,"topic_slug":"splinexs-broach-group-buy-interest","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/kraken-x60-to-sport-gearbox-adapter/472107/4","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Kraken X60 to Sport Gearbox adapter","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/splinexs-broach-group-buy-interest/463206/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3364813,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T03:51:05.906Z","cooked":"

FRC 453 would be interested pending more concrete details. We love our 1/2 inch hex and 3/8 inch hex broaches we bought from AM. They were just as expensive as this and well well worth the price for how often we use them.

My biggest complaint is the length of the broach. The current 1/2 inch one we have is longer than I’d like and it doesn’t fit nicely into our “large” arbor press. This baffles me and it means we have to use 2x4 props and put our stock under the anvil part of the press. It’s such a pain. If it was just 2 inches shorter it would fit.

andymark.com

1/2 in. Hex Broach

1/2" HSS Hexagon Broach

This is 11 7/8 inches long so if it could be shorter like the 3/8 hex broach at 8.5 inches in length would be better for us. Not sure what size you had in mind. I also don’t know enough about broach manufacturing to know if you need that length to get a good cut and more blades to help ease the press. It might not be possible to have a short broach for a large diameter object.

Hex Broach - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":259}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/splinexs-broach-group-buy-interest/463206/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3364817,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-18T04:02:35.238Z","cooked":"
kingc95:

I also don’t know enough about broach manufacturing to know if you need that length to get a good cut and more blades to help ease the press. It might not be possible to have a short broach for a large diameter object.

That’s basically the problem with broaches. Each tooth takes just a little bit of material. Keyway broaches partly solve the length problem by using shims after one pass (though they do tend to be longer as the broach gets bigger). Hex broaches don’t have that option available.

spline-broach-tools900×2000 302 KB

Guess it depends on the profile of the spline but my googling shows some pretty long broaches for stuff like this. Each “bump” or tooth will need its own stepped blades and I can’t see how you can compress that down in length.

I’ve seen people on CD suggest boring a hole in the arbor press ram with a lathe to make this work easier. For example,

Need some recommendations for tooling Manufacturing
Like so. There is an entire 1.75 inches of the broach up in the arbor of this thing. I’d be happy to do it for you, but shipping the arbor would cost more than finding a local team. [image]

(I don’t know if that’s still what Devin would recommend).

Durgabo:

Could you split it across two broaches?

You could, but it would be more expensive and someone could use the wrong one first and for sure break something. I would still suggest the ol drill out the arbor thing. You can go quite deep if you really needed to, drill and ream to the end size say 3 or 4 inches deep, then drill 2 or 3 inches after that to give your broach teeth plenty of clearance.

Small diameter but with more and smaller teeth than a typical gear profile. My worry is we will need it to be long to get nice precision cuts to take off really small amounts at each level. It’s not alot of material, it’s how accurate is the cut on all of the blades over time. Lots of fine small teeth can be damaged easier if you take away too much at a time.

OMG, I’m interested too! The lack of a broach is the most annoying thing in the Kraken ecosystem!

The broach is likely to be in the 5" department; that’s what a 1/16" keyway broach is. If we specified that the maximum cut length was 1" it could get shorter.

I’ve now received a few more quotes, with a very wide range of pricing and specs- I’m expecting to have things narrowed down and finalized by the end of this week. It looks like I should be able to match or beat the $325 price target, and (hopefully) keep the broach relatively similar in size to the AM 3/8 hex broach. Once things are final, I will send a form here to gather information and decide what the best way to handle payments and escrow is.
